abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was highly unsatisfactory, the
            sustainability was highly unlikely, the institutional
            development impact was negligible, the Bank performance was
            unsatisfactory, and the borrower performance was
            unsatisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that because of
            the country's relative wealth (oil & gas revenues)
            and its history of building State Owned Enterprises (SoEs)
            after independence, most of the Algerian
            officials/politicians and part of the population may still
            have been convinced that, after all, the country can afford
            to have poorly performing SoEs and does not need to
            privatize. Intensive supervision can fix a project that may
            have design flaws. In view of this, some regions invest more
            resources in project supervision than in project appraisal,
            given resource constraints. Since political support for
            privatization was still fragile in Algeria, it might have
            been better to distill quickly the benefits of privatization
            achieved in transactions that occurred prior to the
            Bank's loan and communicate these strategically to all
            stakeholders. For institutional sustainability, a Project
            Implementation Unit (PIU) set-up is not necessarily ideal.
            The ambivalence of respective roles needs to be clarified
            ahead of time. This would avoid the question as to what
            extent the Bank should take a position in a specific
            proposed transaction if there is a difference of opinion
            between what an investment bank recommends and what the
            Government is willing to accept in the course of preparing
            bidding documents, particularly if they are deemed as being
            to restrictive.
